This question is really targeted to those who have used Kent Beck's book, T=
est-Driven Development within the context of the NetBeans IDE, otherwise pl=
ease disregard.

Maybe someone here can provide a pointer to already availa=
ble information on this.
I'm using Kent Beck's book, Test-Driven Developmen=
t as a tutorial and was looking at how i might use NetBeans with its JUnit =
plugin to mimic his recommended processes, but right out of the gate I'm ha=
ving a fundamental issue.
A standard practice of KB's method is to code the=
 test before any code is written, and then backfill the empty bits (class, =
methods, variables, etc.) to make the test work.
for example, here's the fi=
rst JUnit test he shows in chapter 1 to begin building from:
Code:
    publ=
ic void testMultiplication() {
        Dollar five =3D new Dollar(5);
     =
   five.times(2);
        assertEquals(10, five.amount);
    }

Problem I'm=
 having is, if I'm creating tests out of the context of the Java project, t=
ests in NB aren't created until you have a class with runtime methods to cr=
eate tests from. So I have a chicken egg sort of situation. NB would do the=
 obvious thing, i.e., have tests generated from code, so the above doesn't =
make any sense as it implies that the code is generated from the test, whic=
h is a cool idea of the IDE could support it.
I have experience using JUnit=
, so the framework itself isn't in question, but how to apply this methodol=
ogy within the IDE format is.
Do I have to simply short-circuit the default=
 process that NB and the JUnit plugin manufacture?

thanks in advance for a=
ny help on this,
Karl
